turns.speaker: MATHESAR
turns.text: "Deception..." "Lies."

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Well... Sort of...

turns.speaker: MATHESAR
turns.text: We have become aware of these concepts only recently. In our dealings with Sarris. Often Sarris will say one thing, and do another. Promise us mercy and deliver destruction... It is a concept we are beginning to learn at some great cost.  But if you are saying that any of you could have traits in common with Sarris.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I'm not a Commander, there is no National Space Exploration Administration. There is no snip.

turns.speaker: MATHESAR
turns.text: But there it is!...

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: A model, only as big as this.

turns.speaker: MATHESAR
turns.text: But... Inside, I have seen-

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Sections of rooms made of plywood. Our Beryllium Sphere was painted wire and plaster. The digital conveyor was Christmas lights... Decorations.  It's all a fake.  I'm not him...  I'm a nothing. A nobody.

turns.speaker: MATHESAR
turns.text: But...Why?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It's difficult to... On our planet we pretend in order to... entertain.

turns.speaker: MATHESAR
turns.text: The ship is a model... As big as this!... A very clever deception indeed! He oan't oontaln hIs lauchter.  A belle-----TOMMY Set a course for home, lommander?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: You can oc that?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: You said we do appearances together, or not at all.'

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I didn't say that.  I said "wouldn't it be great if we could always, work together." That's what I said.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: ... to make sure craft service keeps those little butter cookies, and plenty of them-

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: And determination.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: That's right... Just keep shaking it out... Here, have some gum, It helps.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Wh... Where are we?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Twenty third quadrant of gamma sector.  I can show you on a map.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: I think we're going to exit the space port.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: They designed the ship from watching you. So... Take her out, Lieutenant...

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Well, it's... This was a device we...  discovered on an alien planet.  We don't know what it does either.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Why don't you just turn it on and see?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Just GO! GO! DAMMIT PUNCH GO!

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Faster Tommy. Get us out of here!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: It's as far as it goes!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Could be this.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Push It. Hold it down.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Do your best, Tommy...

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Oh god...

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: All right, Gwen, Alex, Fred, follow me.  Guy, set up the perimeter. Tommy, you keep a lookout, make a signal if they come back.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: What kind of signal?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Anything.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Okay, I'll do this...  "Caw Caw!"

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Tommy, we have these...

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Oh, right, sorry.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Okay, let's go.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Sorry Guys... It just went off.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Good work, Tommy.  Let's go!

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Okay... On what?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: How about the pig-lizard?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Hey I was doing okay with the pig lizard.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Go for the eyes. Like in episode 22 with-

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It doesn't have eyes.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: The throat, the mouth... Its vulnerable spots.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: It's a ROCK. It doesn't HAVE vulnerable spots!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: NO NO NO.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: We've got to get out of here.  C'mon, hurry

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: All right guys... Uh... Gwen and I are going to have to get to the core and shut it down manually. Fred, you and Guy need to get that air valve back on.  Alex, see if you can get the prison doors open downstairs in case Fred and Guy can't get the oxygen back in time.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Jason? What about me? What do I do?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Practice driving, Tommy.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Pedal to the metal Tommy...

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Pedal to the metal...

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Let's do it, Tommy.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Commander?... Call me Laredo?

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Mark 20 Into the black hole,  areao.

turns.speaker: JASON
turns.text: Hold course, Laredo!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I'm trying Commander... Everything's a blur, but as long as I stay locked to that vox signal...

turns.speaker: LATHE
turns.text: Continue forward, sir?

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: Patience, Lt. . Patience.

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: Lieutenant Lathe, I confess I am beginning to feel a bit foolish myself. Chasing across the universe to obtain what is, I am now certain, a bauble of fiction. Tell me how best to obliterate this vessel? I would like nothing to remain.

turns.speaker: LATHE
turns.text: The core could be hardwired to overload without much effort.

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: Find them.

turns.speaker: LATHE
turns.text: But sir, my MEN. The core implosion is not reversible...

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: Find them.

turns.speaker: LATHE
turns.text: enerao, I've host them. The maanetlsm o: the field Is disrupting our onstru- ~ait. There they are

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: Get oacK on their tail.

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: WHAT? WH

turns.speaker: LATHE
turns.text: Because they're coming right at us.

turns.speaker: SARRIS
turns.text: Fire at will. hI~D  NT. PROTECTOR

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Some say that Hessians are invincible.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: They always say that.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Well, now there's something worth dying for.  What do you think?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Hmmm... she's beneath me, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I wish she was beneath me.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Unfortunately, I'll never get the chance.  I'm leaving in an hour for Congress to scream like a violated virgin about my promotion.  Wasting my time, naturally... Look at her teasing those bumpkins.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: What does she see in them?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I'm accused of using some government wagons to ship personal property.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Congress has been using our supply wagons for years to ship their black market goods -- probably their whores!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: We've got to attack the British! Now!  Have they put you in charge yet?  Do we have an army yet?  What is happening?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Patience, Colonel Arnold.  Active personalities terrify these men.  But, congratulations on your victory at Ticonderoga...

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I capture Quebec leading an Army by river fordings through Maine... If we don't do it, the British will come down Champlain, take back Ticonderoga and attack us in the spring.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You'd have to travel hundreds of miles through the wilderness.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Over three hundred miles.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You seem pleased by the prospect.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Exceedingly.  Besides, if I had half the wagons that were used to lug the rum to Philadelphia for this congress, I could move a whole army to the moon!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What's your frank estimation of the British?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Well, you fought with them against the French and Iroquois, how good were they then?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They died well.  Otherwise, they didn't do much right.  But if we have war, the British will surely send their best troops:  right now they have no other enemies.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: And a French alliance?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Ben Franklin's going to Paris, but I think the French will be long on talk and short on guns.  Our troops are mobs, they won't take orders, have no equipment... could they beat the British?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: It comes down to leaders.  If our leaders are ordinary men who truly believe; if they go into the forests with the troops, eat what they eat, fight with them, perhaps to die?  The most common soldier will defy your most depressing expectation.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Arnold!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I've come to report that we've had a bit of luck!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Damn-it!  You've given us a whole new season, Benedict!  And Congress thinks that the British are going to ride right over us come spring. Now half their army is back in Canada.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Congress has picked up it's skirts and is racing for Baltimore. They're not waiting for spring!  Of course, they still had time to deny my promotion.  Even John Adams voted against it...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Why in hell would John do that? Why in hell would any of them do that?  After all you've done, it's unbelievable!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Oh, they have reasons... there's a lot of confusion these days.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They don't trust me, that's the truth isn't it?  Sam Adams never did.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: But trust you to do what?  One side in Congress wants compromise; another glorious battle; some surrender -- some, of course, just want power and money.  But if you don't mind my asking, George, what are your plans?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: We're in bad shape, Benedict, moral is low.  Before I can do anything, I need Lee and his seven thousand troops.  I've ordered him to join us three times.  In my last letter I all but begged him to come here. The man is insubordinate.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: The man's waiting for you to get wiped off the stage so he can become commander and chief.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Go on... I want to hear everything.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Congress is talking -- openly -- about replacing you with Lee.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Is that a fact.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: What do you think, George, shall I resign?  It's what they want.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Don't do anything rash, please, Benedict.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The army needs you.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: The army can survive without me.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Then, I need you.  We all do. Without your victory the men would have no hope at all.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Someday, George, you may need to act for the good of the people no matter what Congress thinks that is.  It may come down to us, or them someday.  You or them.  Cicero was right:  was is 'a time when the laws are silent'.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I hope I never have to believe that.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Christ, George, Joseph Reed's been writing letters back to Congress attacking you.  Your own aide!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: After visiting Congress I know what it's like being violated by come disproportionate asses!  Ah, if she only knew that the most important men in the country -- possibly the world -- are sitting at this table...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: We're so damned important!  Look at us -- Nathanael, you were a horse- shoer, Benedict, before this?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Well, truth be told?  I was a pharmacist.  Alexander?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Well, George, who were you?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I?  You all know my history.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Our plan is to hit them as they leave.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: While they're strung out?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Exactly.  We'd attack the baggage wagons and the rear guard.  It would cause the line to buckle. Then we hit the center with our main force and cut them in half.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They're ready.  Believe me, the ones that stayed on here at Valley Forge are ready for anything.  Of course, we get nothing from Congress.  They need boots, coats... we desperately need food.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Same old story.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: There was this anonymous pamphlet circulated at Congress which says I am personally responsible for all our hardships.  And... that I have encouraged the people of America to make me into a God!  Benedict, it says that I have gone mad!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: That can't be.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: There's this whispering campaign against me ever since Gates won at Saratoga.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Gates?  He used my battle plan and I humbly submit that without me he'd still be back at Saratoga waiting for the British to attack.  George, why haven't you moved into the Potts' house back at the creek? Much more befitting of a Commander and Chief than your field tent. And... you could entertain.  I think you need to entertain more. Seriously!  Get a few New Jersey whores up here, invite some Congressmen... couldn't hurt.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: As soon as the men have good shelters I'll move.  Perhaps Martha will join me this winter.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: There, then, you can have sort of a normal life.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Have you heard?  The British are negotiating to make a trade for General Lee.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I'm sure his dogs will be overjoyed.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The point being:  he's also a candidate for my job.  If we can pull this off, maybe I can restore their faith in me.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: That scum Joseph Reed... they're calling him the 'King of Pennsylvania'.  The man's a budding Cromwell.  He condemns rich Tories to death and then 'appropriates' their property for himself. Naturally, the pig hates me for every Tory I've saved.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Couldn't you have appealed to Congress?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: They love Reed and his inquisition! I think they hope to share in his disgusting profits!  It's becoming the American way!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You go too far, Benedict.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: These men were taken from their homes at night, tried by Reed's courts -- which Congress recognizes -- and, well, you can see.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Cut those men down.  Congress is pushing ahead with your court-martial.  Benedict, trust me to handle this.

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Colonel, sir, Mrs. Washington inquires if you are going to join her for dinner?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Tell Mrs. Washington I am compelled to stay a while longer.

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: You, you just need a new flint, General.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You are never, never to touch my guns!  Do you understand!?

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Yes, General.  But if you have to shoot somebody, you can't.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: None of the servants is to touch a gun!  You know that!

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Well... I misunderstood, then.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Misunderstood what!?

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: A lot of years have gone by.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What?  What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: That you would have known you can trust me.

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Me?  You apologizing to me?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Yes, William.  I am apologizing.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Wil...

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Yes, general?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You've served me loyally, year after year, without complaining. I've thought hard about you this past winter.  I want to free you, Wil.  I want to give you your freedom, after this battle is fought.

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Yes, general.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Wil, I'm giving you your freedom. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: No.  I guess.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You'd have money every year, so you wouldn't have to work.  You can stay at Mount Vernon as long as you want...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Wil, I want to remind you of a conversation we started just before Monmouth...

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: I ain't forgot about the freedom.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Well, what have you thought?

turns.speaker: BILLY LEE
turns.text: Well, general, I think I ain't got no school learning, I ain't got no trade... and I'm a drunk.  So, I think there ain't much left to be set free.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: No uniforms.  No coats, even?  In this weather?

turns.speaker: MAWHOOD
turns.text: No, my lord.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: What sort of boots would you say he's wearing?  I should say, no sort of boots at all.  Aren't those rags wrapped around his feet?  Is that what he marched here in?

turns.speaker: MAWHOOD
turns.text: Yes, my lord.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: And, is that a pitchfork beside him?

turns.speaker: MAWHOOD
turns.text: Many of them, many did not possess proper arms.  My lord.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Negroes?  Washington has black men in his army?  Are they good fighters?  What's that red ribbon on his arm, Colonel?

turns.speaker: MAWHOOD
turns.text: Because they have hardly any uniforms, they designate officers with colored ribbons.  My lord.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: By red, what rank would you say this black, officer, soldier is, Colonel?

turns.speaker: MAWHOOD
turns.text: I, don't know what color is what officer, my lord...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: General Lee, welcome back.  I'm happy you've decided to join us.

turns.speaker: GENERAL LEE
turns.text: More than that, sir... my orders from Congress.

turns.speaker: GENERAL LEE
turns.text: I am to take command of Major General Lafayette's division and lead the attack.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Lafayette will not be happy...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What the goddamned hell do you think you are doing!?

turns.speaker: GENERAL LEE
turns.text: The British!  These men cannot stand against them!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What do you know about these men!? They can stand against anything! They've seen more war than most field generals!  They are not cowards, sir!  They are not afraid!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Who is that!?

turns.speaker: GENERAL LEE
turns.text: That's Greene.  He's supporting our reconsolidation.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Marquis!  Get these men reformed, send Steuben and Wayne out on the left...

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Captain Alexander Hamilton, sir!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Hamilton, you're going to have to cover our asses as we cross.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: We've got powder but no ball!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Then use rocks!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: How old are you, Captain?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: I'll be twenty next year, sir.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I'll expect you for dinner this evening, Captain Hamilton.  For Christ's sake, have a bath.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Delighted, sir.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Excuse me, General, but may I ask how do you feel?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: No one wants to turn the table on the enemy more than I.  But if victory is remote and there's any hope for a negotiated peace, we must keep this army intact.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Therefore, retreat.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I'm so inclined.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Well, sir, then is it possible you called us all here just to hear what you wanted to hear.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: General Washington, is there actually going to be a compromise, I mean, a 'deal' with England?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: And is that the most horrible thing in the world?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Captain, I want you to know that I respect your openness.  It would make me happy if you'd join our table for dinner from now on.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: With pleasure... and an honor.  Did you hear about Nathan Hale?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: That young school teacher... I heard the British hung him as a spy.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: But it's what he said, just before they killed him:  "I regret that I have but one life to give to my country."

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They're among the best divisions the British have.  No conscripts, no impressed recruits, just professional killers.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: It's a wonder they find the British cause worth dying for.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: I was a clerk's apprentice on Saint Croix.  But, then I went to King's College.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: To learn to shoot cannon?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Are you going to keep him, sir?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: We better, Congress invented him.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: It's impossible to stop these men deserting in winter, you might as well stop geese from migrating.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: They go back home to keep their families alive, stay into the spring to plant.  Then, they start coming back to us.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: What are we going to do?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Get the body of our army up to Greene's vanguard as fast as we can.  All the damned fool has to do is hit the British rearguard and then hold for us.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: General Greene is here.  There are two other divisions here.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Colonel Hamilton.  Anyone who served under Arnold, I want them shipped north.  I don't want any troops here who served under Arnold.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Yessir.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Did you know that Arnold left the entire defenses of this fort in complete disrepair?  Most of our cannons are so neglected they may as well have been spiked!?  You realize what would happen if this fort fell?  The whole Hudson would be open to them!

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Sir, I think no such thing.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Don't lie to me, Hamilton!  If I had not court-martialed Arnold...

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Sir, Arnold is a traitor.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I must tell you sir you treat me with disrespect!

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: I am not conscious of it, sir!  But since you have thought it necessary to tell me so, we part!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What is this?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Congress has informed the army that it is bankrupt and cannot pay the soldiers pensions.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: This is a declaration of insurrection!  Who wrote this!?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: No one knows...

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: George, remember that night when we were drinking with Arnold?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: To hell with Arnold...

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: He warned you some day you might have to act for the good of the people -- even if it was against Congress.  George, the time has come for you to declare yourself king of America.  Listen to me, the whole army would rise up as one and place you on a throne!  George, you must declare yourself with us or against us.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Is this a coup?  Alexander, are you trying to tell me that I might be assassinated if I don't agree?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What's your advice, Alexander?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: March on Philadelphia!  Get Joseph Reed, and the pigs in Congress, the speculators, who've grown fat off the war!  Get them all!  Sweep them aside!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I want to address the officers, all the officers.  Next Friday.  Can we arrange it at the mess?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Yes, I believe so.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Well, if it's my last order, then I order them to be there!  Tell them I will give them my decision then.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: Have you decided if you are going to join the Virginia Delegation to the Constitutional Convention?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: George, you're the only man the people trust... trust with power. They know you won't betray them.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: But it's more than just that, am I right?

turns.speaker: HAMILTON
turns.text: That's why the people trust you George.  Without someone at the convention, who has the people behind him, everything will fail. Will you do it?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You're asking me to be president of a republic, not king?  Not a dictator over subjects?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Horatio!  Horatio Gates, of course you know John Adams of the Massachusetts Delegation.

turns.speaker: HORATIO GATES
turns.text: Good day, Mister Adams... George, what's the word from Boston?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The last I heard, a bunch of drunken militia have dug in on Breed's hill.  With one stroke the British could cut them off and apparently their leaders are too dumb to see it.

turns.speaker: HORATIO GATES
turns.text: Who's in command out there?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Who the hell knows?  Everyone's giving orders.  It's all very democratic.

turns.speaker: HORATIO GATES
turns.text: George, we've got to get you out there before we lose our whole army.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Well, John Adams, your cousin has a marvelous gift.

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Yes, an astonishing power over weak minds.

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: With your support, Horatio.  As one of our own who has seen combat with the British, your opinion counts.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: As does your ability, Horatio.  We must talk further, when it's more convenient.

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: You won't be needing his largess, Rhode Island is already committed to your appointment.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I don't know:  delivering men and delivering men with their goodwill are two different things.  And, if he's popular with his men...

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Colonel Charles Lee... Hounds and all.  Quite the character.  He's got a tremendous reputation.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I think many would like to see him commander-in-chief.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: If he supports the British why is it that every time he gets near them he kills so many of them?  Unlike General Lee... who you and Congress backed for second in command and who is a goddamned incompetent!

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Lafayette is a child!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Lafayette is my friend!  He believes in glory and truth and the freedom of all mankind; so, of course he's a child.  But he would have died before he would have let me down.

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: George, I'm sorry.  We all know the army will acquit Arnold...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Of course the army will acquit him, that's not the point... Arnold is a man and will understand.  What I need to understand is, John, Sam... what is happening here?  Who are those people in there?  The fat ones in silk?

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: They are... friends of Congress.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Is that where our meat and boots and uniforms and muskets went?

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Washington is perfect.  He's a Southerner, he's a war hero and he's rich!

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: He's from Virginia -- there is no more classist, elitist... English place on earth than Virginia.  And, what in hell has he done for our cause?  Washington has been preaching compromise, compromise, compromise!  Hancock acts, he led the Boston Tea party!  That's why New England loves him.

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Hancock led the Boston 'tea party' because he's a goddamned tea smuggler!  He wasn't protesting inequality, he was eliminating competition.  Now, you listen to me:  we need to get a Southerner elected commander-in-chief, or the south will not fight!  What have we been struggling for all these years?  For this moment!  And, if we fail now, remember:  you stopped us!

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Let's not over do it...

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: I tell you every damned place I go the man is adored!  "General Washington!  Champion of Trenton! Savior of the Republic!"  And you should hear the way people are deprecating Congress!

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Makes you gag.

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: Gag on your own invention, then.

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Oh, come now...

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: You invented this, this...

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: You think that?

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: He has the soul of an aristocrat who'd like nothing more than to become a king in the minds of the people!

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: No one wants another failure right now, God knows.  But people like Arnold and, God knows, I'm having my fears about General Washington.

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: Finally!?  It's people like these who, as soon as they get a little power, want more and more.  More ale, here!

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Again, just to touch on a touchy subject, but... would the people accept another leader over Washington?

turns.speaker: JOHN ADAMS
turns.text: Partially...

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: It's the political 'cost of doing business', George.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I doubt Arnold will be afraid.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: If he isn't, then he's stupid.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Did God ever make such a pitiful army?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: These men have suffered but I believe they will fight.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: No officer is going to get these men to fight!  They had the life crushed out of them on Long Island. At the most, perhaps we could make a feint at an outpost, then retire to protect Congress.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I hear General Lee is holding seven thousand fresh infantry back in New York -- why won't he come on!?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: General Lee is detained captain...

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Detained by what?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: The British army, sir!

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: The British Army is right back there, across that river!  Sir!  I think it must be something else that detains General Lee.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Congress is bitterly opposed to allowing Negroes in the army!

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: We already have black soldiers in our army...

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Unofficially, General Greene.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: What's the difference?
